response.answer_text: AMIMOTO-AMI Managed Wordpress Hosting. It’s mind-bogglingly fast. After a month of experimenting with the self-hosted builds they offer, this I finally pulled the trigger and my company is coming on board with them for fully-managed AWS hosting. For the last 4 years, my we’ve been on the fastest dedicated server that Dreamhost offers, running a standard LAMP stack. It’s a big machine: a 16-core Xeon processor with 64 gigs of RAM and a 512 gig SSD hard drive. It’s fast, too - in fact, I did comparison testing and it beat a comparable offering by Rackspace for about half the monthly price. In late August, Dreamhost got hit by a massive DDOS - probably in retaliation for the disruptj20 issue back in August: “DreamHost hit the headlines earlier this month when the US Department of Justice demanded 1.3 million IP addresses of people who visited disruptj20 dot org, a website organizing protests during President Trump's inauguration that was hosted by the biz. The warrant also demanded the contact information, submitted comments, email content, and photos of thousands of people who used the site.” Whatever inspired the attack, it knocked us out of commission and pushed us into action - looking for a secure, stable cloud-based hosting platform with a provider big enough to withstand DDOS attacks. Dreamhost is good, but we wanted something better. Our choice was simple: we’ve used Amazon Web Services for our CDN for a while - so why not go the distance and move everything over? Why screw around with mid-sized hosting providers when we can take everything into the cloud with the biggest, fastest, most scalable network available? After a bit more research, we found AMIMOTO-AMI, which runs 100% on top of Amazon. What makes this company special is that they launch & manage custom-built instances of an NPP-Wordpress stack, and they offer both self-managed and fully-managed options. NPP means that it’s using the Nginx web-server, PHP 7, and a tuned Percona database - along with some custom caching tools that AMIMOTO threw in. The most important part is the stack, though, which literally just eats standard LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP) servers for lunch. I spent about 2 weeks tinkering with the self-managed option, and was literally stunned by the speed comparison. Our fastest sites, implementing all the latest technologies, served literally 3x faster with AMIMOTO on an AWS M3 server. They cost more than Dreamhost, but less than WP-Engine, and since they’re a newer organization they’ve bent over backwards to help us migrate. So far, zero complaints!
